column2:
One thing was certain with communism, you were guaranteed a job but “who knows where in the country? [For example] Let’s presume you finished medicine. You became a young doctor, but who knows where in a little village in Romania." - Museum Manager
Jobs were limited: army, engineer, doctor, professor, factory worker, or, if skilled, a sportsman. Family pressure pushed for jobs like lawyer, doctor, or pilot. Assignments were often far from home, in villages in the middle of nowhere, with no choice of the destination.
column3:
"Cine ştie unde în ţară te repartizau, dar tu aveai slujba. Să presupunem că ai terminat medicina. Ai devenit un doctor tânăr, dar cine știe unde într-un mic sat din România." - Manager Muzeu
Accesul la locurile de muncă a fost limitat: militar, inginer, doctor, profesor, lucrător în fabrică sau, dacă este calificat, sportiv. Presiunea familiei era  pentru locuri de muncă precum avocat, medic sau pilot. Repartizările erau adesea departe de casă, în sate în mijlocul pustietății, fără posibilitatea de a alege destinația.

column2:
"After finishing my studies, I would have been sent [by the state] to go as a teacher somewhere in the countryside [as it was mandatory].” - Journalist
University was mostly for students to obtain technical degress that would help in industrialization, construction, education, and health. After graduating, students were sent anywhere in the country where there was a need for 'repartisare.' University was especially attractive to young men because they could shorten their mandatory military service.
column3:
"După terminarea studiilor, eram trimis să merg ca profesor undeva în mediul rural prin repartizare guvernamentală." - Jurnalist
Universitatea a fost o modalitate pentru studenți de se specializa în domenii precum industrializare, construcții, educație și sănătate. După absolvire, studenții au fost trimiși oriunde în țara pe baza principiului 'repartizării.' Universitatea a fost deosebit de atractivă pentru tineri, deoarece scurta  perioada serviciului militar obligatoriu.

"I became very attractive as a German-speaking student for the Securitate… they needed a translator to accompany a young secretary of the central committee of the young communists. One of their bosses got invited to a conference in West Germany and they selected me to be a translator... they were testing me. I then defected." - Journalist
Emigration was nearly impossible and trying to escape the country was met with rejection, arrest, and imprisonment. You could only leave if you were a sportsman or had special permission. You were forced to provide information to the regime upon your return.
column3:
"Am devenit foarte atrăgător pentru Securitate ca student vorbitor de limbă germană. Au avut nevoie de un traducător care să însoțească un tânăr secretar al comitetului central al tinerilor comuniști. Unul dintre șefii lor a fost invitat la o conferință în Germania de Vest și m-au selectat să fiu traducător.... de fapt era un test din partea lor. Apoi am dezertat."" - Jurnalist
Emigrarea a fost aproape imposibilă și încercarea de a scăpa din țară a fost întâmpinată cu respingere, arestare și închisoare. Puteai pleca doar dacă erai  sportiv sau exista o permisiune specială dată de Partid. La întoarcere erai forțat  să furnizezi informaţii regimului.

column2:
"The fourth grade [Pioneers promoted the students from] the second grade [to become] Pioneers" - Museum Manager
Pioneers are a ranking in schools from 2nd-8th grade, which was indicated by wearing a red scarf. Pioneers were young children being prepared for future membership in the Communist party. They participated in party festivals and training programs. Many school children struggled to become Pioneer status because it gave them more social power in school.
column3:
În clasa a patra [pionierii  promovau elevii de clasa a doua [pentru a deveni] la rândul lor pionieri" - Manager de muzeu
Pionierii constituie un detașament în cadrul școlilor gimnaziale, clasele a 2-a și a 8-a, care se definea  prin purtarea unei eșarfe roșii. Pionierii au fost copii mici pregătiți pentru viitoarea aderare la Partidul Comunist. Au participat la festivalurile şi programele de instruire ale partidului . Mulți studenți s-au străduit să obțină statutul de pionieri, deoarece le-a dat mai multă putere socială în școală.

column2:
“You were not supposed to understand why, you were just obliged to do it. This way, they manipulated you to lose your inner self and become a part of collectivity.” - Museum Manager
Civilians were forced to attend Communist Party state festivities that promoted communist ideologies and praising Nicolae Ceaușescu. Consequences for not attending could include being fired from your job or invasive surveillance.
column3:
“Nu trebuia să  înțelegi de ce, erai doar obligat să o faci. În acest fel, erai manipulat să-ți pierzi sinele interior și să devii parte a colectivului.” - Museum Manager
Civilii au fost forțați să participe la festivitățile de stat ale Partidului Comunist care promovau ideologia comunistă și îl lăudau pe Nicolae Ceaușescu. Consecințele pentru a nu participa puteau varia de la concedierea de la locul de muncă sau intrai în colimatorul Securității

column2:
"We didn't have TV, you know. It was only for two hours during the evening when the whole program was only about Ceaușescu. It was nothing else." - Museum Director
Books, movies, and news were available but all were censored to control information and prevent criticism of the regime. The role of the media was to spread state propaganda, convincing people that Ceaușescu was a great leader and that life was better than it really was. Products forbidden by the state, especially music and literature, could only be found on the black market.
column3:
"Nu am avut TV, ştiţi. Erau doar două ore seara când tot programul era doar despre Ceauşescu. Nu era difuzat nimic altceva." - Director de muzeu
Cărți, filme și știri au fost disponibile, dar toate cenzurate pentru a controla informațiile și pentru a preveni criticile la adresa regimului. Rolul televiziunii, al presei și radioului a fost de a răspândi propaganda de stat, convingând oamenii că Ceauşescu era un mare lider şi că viaţa era mai bună decât era în realitate. Produsele interzise de cenzură, în special literatura și muzica, au fost vândute pe piața negră.

column2:
"We have to deal with rations, because if we want to buy usual stuff like oil or gas or bread or meat or butter, we have to have the cards, the tickets for the rations." - Museum Director
Rations = fixed amount of goods that citizens are allowed to consume in times of shortages. Rations were placed on basic necessities like food, cooking oil, soaps, gasoline, electricity, and heating.
column3:
"Trebuia să ne gestionăm raţiile de hrană alocate de stat, pentru că achiziția de lucruri obişnuite, cum ar fi petrol sau gaz, pâine sau carne sau unt se baza întotdeauna pe cartele de hrană." - Director Muzeu
Rație = cantitatea fixă de bunuri pe care cetățenii au voie să o consume în perioade de penurie. Rațiile au fost plasate pe necesități de bază, cum ar fi alimente, ulei de gătit, săpunuri, benzină, electricitate și încălzire."

column2:
"Parents fought to create some sense of normalcy in the midst of the disaster that was reality." - School Teacher
Many children were protected from the harshness of life by their parents but some still knew that the propaganda was lies. Children had to do chores, wait in the ration queues, and do homework in the dark. But, they still had hobbies and played with their friends.
column3:
"Părinții s-au luptat pentru a crea un sentiment de normalitate în mijlocul dezastrului care a fost realitatea." - Profesor de școală
Mulți copii au fost protejați de duritatea vieții de către părinții lor, dar unii știau că propaganda era minciună. Copiii trebuiau să facă activități de propagandă, să aștepte în cozile de rație și să-și facă temele în întuneric.

column2:
"Not because you didn't have money, but because you can not find other things." - Museum Director
Food was scarce and there was no variety in stores. Basic necessities were rationed and of much worse quality compared to today. Queues to collect rations were long and often started in the very early morning.
column3:
"Nu pentru că nu ai avut bani, ci pentru că nu poţi găsi alte lucruri." - Director Muzeu
Mâncarea era insuficientă și nu exista varietate în magazine. Produsele de bază au fost raţionalizate şi de o calitate mult mai proastă în comparaţie cu cea de astăzi. Cozile pentru colectarea rațiilor erau  lungi și de multe ori începeau dimineața foarte devreme.

column2:
"We were like soldiers in school." - Museum Manager
School was very strict. The party wanted to demonstrate how educated and proper its citizens were - kids were even required to write in ink in a calligraphy style. All classrooms had a portrait of Ceaușescu and students had to repeat chants about the Romanian Communist Party and how great Ceaușescu was every day. There were lessons about the communist ideology and students were punished for not being able to recite Ceaușescu's policies and speeches.
column3:
"Am fost ca soldații în școală." - Manager de muzeu
Școala era foarte strictă. Partidul a vrut să demonstreze cât de educați și de integrabili erau cetățenii săi - copiii erau obligați să scrie cu cerneală, motivul ținea de dezvoltarea caligrafiei. Toate sălile de clasă aveau un portret al lui Ceauşescu, iar elevii trebuiau să fie îndoctrinați cu valorile Partidul Comunist Român şi despre cât de mărețe erau relizările lui Ceauşescu în fiecare zi. Erau și lecţii despre ideologia comunistă, iar elevii puteau fi pedepsiţi pentru că nu erua la zi cu  politicile şi discursurile lui Ceauşescu.

column2:
"Young people [who] wrote we want food, freedom on walls were seen as people who were dangerous to the regime and were [arrested]." - Museographer 
The Securitate forcefully relocated people that were perceived as dangerous to the Communist Party. The purpose of these camps was to re-educate these people and prevent uprisings. People were often falsely accused and relocated as a result. The conditions were rough and prisoners were rarely allowed to see thier families.
column3:
"Tinerii [care] scriau că vrem mâncare, libertatea pe ziduri au fost văzuți ca un pericol pentru regim şi au fost [arestaţi]." - Muzeograf 
Securitatea a relocat cu forţa oameni care erau percepuţi ca periculoşi pentru Partidul Comunist. Scopul acestor tabere a fost de a reeduca aceste persoane și de a preveni revoltele. Oamenii au fost adesea acuzați în mod fals și relocați ca rezultat. Condițiile erau dure, iar prizonierilor li se permitea rareori să vadă familii mai înalte.

column2: Who went to deportation camps?
column3: Cine a fost deportat?

column2:
"The actual Romania didn't exist for me anymore. [Mainly] because the neighborhood where I lived, where I was born, my house, my street, my neighborhood was pulled down." - Journalist
The Palace of Parliament was originally known as the House of the People when Ceauseșcu ordered for it's constrcution. Construction began in the 1980s, part of Ceauseșcu's goal to rebuild and mimic the capital city of North Korea. Seven square kilometers of neighborhoods were destroyed to make room for the House of the People. Part of the money for this project came for relief funds for earthquake victims and cost the country more than 3 billion Euros.
column3:
"România reală nu mai exista pentru mine. [În principal] pentru că întreg cartierul în care am locuit, unde m-am născut, casa mea, strada mea au fost demolate."- Jurnalist
Palatul Parlamentului a fost inițial cunoscut sub numele de Casa Poporului atunci când Ceaușescu a ordonat construcția. Totul a început în anii 1980, parte a obiectivului lui Ceaușeșcu de a reconstrui și imita capitala Coreei de Nord. Șapte kilometri pătrați de cartiere au fost distruse pentru a face loc Casei Poporului. O parte din banii pentru acest proiect au venit prin fonduri de ajutorare pentru victimele cutremurului, iar costul final al proiectului de depășit 3 miliarde de euro.

column2:
"We thought that our destiny was completely destroyed but we did not complain. Just fought." - AFDPR Member
People living under communism felt a mix of fear, anger, frustration, and hopelessness. Fear came from constantly being watched and reported. Frustration came from extreme shortages and harsh rules. Deep inside, many people still held onto hope. They dreamed of freedom and a better life.
column3:
"Am crezut că destinul nostru a fost complet distrus, dar nu ne-am plâns. Am luptat." - Membru AFDPR
Oamenii care sub comunism au simțit un amestec de frică, furie, frustrare și lipsă de speranță. Frica a venit pe fundalul de a fi urmărit și raportat în mod constant. Frustrarea s-a datorat  lipsurilor extreme și a regulilor dure. În adâncul sufletului, mulți oameni încă mai aveau speranță. Visau la libertate şi la o viaţă mai bună.

column2: What emotions did people feel while living under communism?
column3: Care au fost principalele emoții trăite de oameni în comunism?

column2:
"My father was a priest which was an unhealthy origin." - History Teacher
Those who came from religious families were said to have unhealthy origins. Students that went to church on Sundays could be punished by their teachers and could prevent them from having other opportunities such as getting into a university.
column3:
"Tatăl meu a fost un preot cu origine nesănătoasă." - Învățător de istorie
Cei care proveneau din familii religioase erau catalogați ca având origini nesănătoase. Elevii care mergeau la biserică duminica puteau fi pedepsiţi de profesorii lor şi puteau suferi consecințe mult mai ample, cum ar fi limitarea accesului la studii universitare.

column3: Care era statutul religiei în comunism?

column2:
"The economy was going so badly due to Ceaușescu's poor leadership and idiotic investments in heavy industries… unsustainable, no raw materials, no energy, not enough of a work force." - Activist
Romania exported a lot of products, especially during the 1980s, to pay off foreign debts. These included food like grains, meat, and oil, machinery, textiles, and cars. The state sent loads of resources to other countries while Romanians at home faced extreme shortages and empty shelves.
column3:
"Economia mergea atât de rău din cauza conducerii slabe a lui Ceauşescu şi a investiţiilor idioate în industriile grele, nesustenabile, fără materii prime, fără energie, fără suficientă forţă de muncă." - Activist.
România a exportat o mulțime de produse, în special în anii 1980, pentru a plăti datoriile externe. Acestea includeau alimente precum cereale, carne și ulei, mașini, textile și utilaje. Statul a exportart resurse esențiale, în timp ce românii de acasă s-au confruntat cu lipsuri extreme și rafturi goale.

column3: Ce tipuri de produse românești erau exportate?

column2:
"The Romanian people were not allowed to cross the border. We were not allowed to read [foreign magazines]. We couldn't find them. We were not allowed to read the foreign newspapers." - AFDPR Member
No relationships with foreigners were allowed unless they were reported and approved by the Communist Party. Romanians were harshly limited on places they could travel to and it was hard to obtain visas for travel. Contacting people in foreign countries, even family memebrs, was harshly regulated.
column3:
"Poporul român nu avea voie să treacă frontiera. Nu ni s-a permis să citim [reviste străine].Nu le-am putut găsi. Nu ni s-a permis să citim ziarele străine." - Membru AFDPR
Nu erau fost permise relaţiile cu străinii decât dacă erau raportate şi aprobate de Partidul Comunist. Românii erau extrem de limitați în locurile în care puteau călători și era greu să obțină vize pentru călătorii. Contactarea persoanelor din țări străine, chiar și a membrilor de familie care locuiau în vest, a fost strict reglementată.

column2: How did Romanian's interact with people in foreign countries?
column3: Cum interacționau românii cu cetățenii din țări străine?

column2:
"When the communists came, [citizens] had to give it away just like that. Everything that they had - cows, sheep, horses - it wasn't theirs. It was the government's." - School Teacher
They were often confiscated, controlled, or heavily monitored. Items that the Securitate labeled as "Western" or anti-regime were destroyed or hidden. The state could seize property whenever they wanted and many people lived in fear of losing their belongings. This process was called "collectivization" and was a key part of Stalinism.
column3:
"Când au venit comuniştii, [cetăţenii] au trebuit să renunţe la proprietățile lor pur și simplu. Tot ce aveau - vaci, oi, cai - nu era al lor. A devenit proprietatea statului." - Profesor de școală
Averile au fost confiscate, controlate și monitorizate de guvern. Bunuri pe care Securitatea le putea eticheta ca "occidentale" sau anti-regim au fost distruse sau ascunse. Statul putea să confiște bunurile private fără notificare, astfel că mulți cetățeni trăiau cu teama de a-și pierde bunurile. Acest proces a fost numit "colectivizare" și a fost o parte esențială a instaurării regimului comunist de tip stalinist în România.

column2: What happened to people's private posessions?
column3: Ce s-a întâmplat cu proprietatea privata?

column2:
"Ceaușescu, RCP. Ceaușescu, RCP." - Museum Manager
Party figures spoke in a rigid, artifical style like "wooden language." It was a soulless way of talking that erased people's thoughts and expression. Words became like weapons of control and submission.
column3:
"Ceauşescu, PCR. Ceauşescu, PCR." - Manager Muzeu
Figurile de partid vorbeau într-un stil rigid, artifical definit ca "limbajul de lemn." A fost un mod de exprimare fără substanță, superficial care fost folosit cu precădere pentru a nivela gândurile și expresivitatea oamenilor. Cuvintele au devenit  arme folosite pentru a controla și supune liberul arbitru.

column2: How did politicians speak during the time?
column3: Cum vorbeau politicienii în acea perioadă?

column2: "Ceaușescu, RCP. Ceaușescu, RCP." - Museum Manager
column3: "Ceauşescu, PCR. Ceauşescu, PCR." - Manager Muzeu

column2:
"The Securitate’s weapon was propaganda. The [former] Securitate are good at changing history even now, contributing to today’s nostalgia [to return to communism]." - Activist
Propaganda = newspapers, TV, posters and pedagogy were used to manipulate the thinking and influence of people's speech, all with the stated purpose of maintaining population control. PAD controlled all information and media, thus nurturing the cult of personality for Ceausescu, hence promoting socialist ideals through propaganda. This department within the Securitate was responsible for limiting and controlling cultural diversity in Romania
column3:
"Arma Securității a fost propaganda. [fosta] Securitatea a fost abilă în a schimba narativul istoric, efectele se văd chiar şi acum, ceea ce contribuie la menținerea nostalgiei de astăzi [de a reveni la regimul comunism]." - Activist
Propaganda = ziare, TV, postere și pedagogie utilizate pentru a manipula gândirea și influența vorbirea oamenilor, totul cu scopul declarat de a menține controlul populației. column2: In the wake of a devastating 1977 earthquake, Ceaușescu seized the opportunity to destroy entire neighborhoods (more than 1450 ha) in Bucharest to create new Communist Party headquarters and housing for visiting diplomats and politicians. This headquarters, named the "People's House" was constructed on a hill and used roughly 30% of Romania's GDP and used up significant amounts of Romania's natural resources. The 12 story tall 'house' was lit up with ornate chandieliers despite light bulbs' scarcity. Due to the land the palace and the boulevard leading to it took, roughly 9,300 homes were demolished, leaving 50,000 families displaced and homeless . Note that the building was constructed as the "People's House", but was renamed after the success of the revolution in 1989 as the "Palace of Parliament" as it is known today.
column3: În urma cutremurului devastator din 1977, Ceaușescu a profitat de context pentru a iniția distrugerea  de cartiere întregi (peste 1450 hectare) din București pentru a crea un nou sediu al Partidului Comunist, alături de  locuințe pentru diplomați și politicieni. Acest sediu, numit "Casa Poporului", a fost construit pe un deal și a folosit aproximativ 30% din PIB-ul României, consumând cantități semnificative din resursele naturale ale României. 'Casa' de doar 12 etaje   a fost luminată de candelabre luxoase într-o perioadă în care familiile puteau obține doar un singur bec pe lună. Planul de construcție viza dezvoltarea clădirii și a unui bulevard amplu ceea ce a condus la demolarea a aproximativ 9.300 de case, iar în plan social s-a tradus în  50.000 de familii strămutate și fără adăpost. Clădirea a fost construită sub denumirea de "Casa Poporului", dar a fost redenumită după Revoluției din 1989 drept "Palatul Parlamentului", așa cum este cunoscută astăzi.

The July Theses were a set of ideas and rules announced by Nicolae Ceaușescu in July 1971 after he visited China and North Korea, two countries with very strict communist systems. He was impressed by how those countries governments controlled their people and wanted to bring similar ideas to Romania.
 The July Theses included:
* More censorship of books, newspapers, TV, and movies. 
* Less freedom of speech — people were not allowed to criticize the government.
* Tighter control over education — schools had to teach communist ideas and praise the Ceaușescu family.
* More political propaganda — the media had to constantly show support for the Communist Party.
* Increased focus on nationalism — teaching that Romania was great and strong because of its leaders.
* Restrictions on Western culture — music, clothes, and ideas from other countries were discouraged or banned.
The July Theses marked the start of a harsher, more repressive period in Romania. Ceaușescu wanted to control what people thought, said, and listened to. This shift made life even harder for many Romanians, especially for students, writers, and artists who wanted more freedom.

The Romanian Communist Party was founded on May 8th, 1921. After World War II, the party was influenced by the Soviet Union and its leader, Joseph Stalin. The communists slowly took control by using propaganda and taking advantage of other political parties’ weaknesses. Communism officially started in Romania in 1947, when King Michael I was forced to give up the throne and the country became a communist republic.
Ana Pauker was an intellectual and was the unofficial prime minister of Romania's communist party after WWII. She was a strong believer in Stalinist ideology, a totalitarian political regime lead by Joseph Stalin. The main policies of his regime were rapid induztrialization, cultural revolution, and a reorginization of agricultural output.
While she supported Stalinism, she did not believe in the reorganization of all industries for governmental control and did allow for emigration of the Jewish population - something not seen in other communist leaders at the time. Pauker was the first woman to hold such a position in the Communist Party. In 1952, she was ousted of her position by Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej and was placed under arrest as a result due to the political risk she posed to Gheorghiu-Dej.

The Revolution of 1989 was a major turning point in Romanian history. It began with protests in Timișoara, sparked by the government’s attempt to deport pastor László Tőkés. These protests quickly spread across the country, growing into a nationwide uprising against the brutal regime of Nicolae Ceaușescu. 
Over the course of a week, demonstrations turned violent as the Securitate tried to crush the revolt. Over 1,000 people were killed and thousands more were injured during the clashes. Eventually, the pressure became too much for the Securitate. Nicolae and Elena Ceaușescu were arrested, tried in a military court, and executed on December 25th, 1989. The revolution brought an end to decades of dictatorship and marked the beginning of Romania’s transition to democracy.

column2: Nicolae Ceaușescu was the leader of communist Romania from 1965-1989. At first, some people supported him because he spoke out against the Soviet Union, which made him seem independent and strong. However, over time, he became more authoritarian —  he demanded total control and didn’t allow others to disagree with him. Under Ceaușescu’s rule, life became very difficult for Romanian citizens. There were severe food and energy shortages, and people had almost no freedom of speech or movement. A powerful secret police force called the Securitate spied on citizens, creating an atmosphere of fear and mistrust. Ceaușescu also forced the country into huge construction projects, like the Palace of the Parliament in Bucharest — one of the largest governmental buildings in the world. These projects cost billions of euros and were meant to show off his power, while most people lived in poverty and hardship. Today, Ceaușescu is remembered as one of Europe’s most repressive and controlling dictators.

column2: Elena Ceaușescu was the wife of Nicolae Ceaușescu. Over time, she became one of the most powerful people in the country, even though she had little education and no real qualifications. Despite this, she was given high-ranking government positions, including Deputy Prime Minister and head of several scientific institutions. She was also president of Scientific Council of the Central Institute of Chemistry, but most of her academic titles and awards were fake or exaggerated. Her power came mainly from her close relationship with Nicolae as his “direct correspondent,” she used it to promote herself and control others. Elena was known for being arrogant, strict, and deeply disliked by many Romanians. She was heavily involved in government decisions and is believed to have helped create the harsh policies that led to poverty, fear, and repression during the 1980s.

Marxism is a way of thinking about society, economics, and politics that was created by Karl Marx. It is the idea that society is divided into two main groups: the rich (bourgeoisie) – who own businesses, land, and factories - and the working class (proletariat) – who work for the rich but don’t own much themselves. Marx believed this wasn’t fair and believed that the workers should come together, take control of the economy, and share things more equally. The goal of Marxism is to create a society where everyone is equal, and there’s no rich or poor. 
Sovietization stemmed from Marxism, as the Soviet Union attempted to put Marx’s ideas into practice by abolishing private property, redistributing wealth, and establishing a state-controlled economy in the name of equality and socialism.

After World War II, Romania fell under heavy Soviet influence. Under Gheorghe Gherogiu-Dej, the country underwent a process of "Sovietization," which promoted Stalinist policies such as collectivization of agriculture and repression of any anti-ideology actions. 
However, in the 1960s, after the death of Joseph Stalin and the subsequent de-Stalinization under Khrushchev, Romania began to distance itself from the USSR’s direct control. While still maintaining a Marxist-Leninist political structure, Gheorgiu-Dej emphasized national sovereignty and pursued a more independent foreign policy. Romania improved its relations with neighboring socialist countries such as Bulgaria and Yugoslavia, and advocated for denuclearization and greater autonomy within the Eastern Bloc.
